I really love this channel, so finding a video on this topic was not surprising but intriguing. It's definitely an engineer's view, of course, that's the whole idea of the channel. But I think you can't engineer you way out of some problems.

You frame the discussion in terms of the Second Amendment, which is a thing that no other other countries have. They also don't generally have the problem that the US is plagued with – dead children in school corridors. I don't actually think this is simple causality: the Second Amendment doesn't cause school shootings. But there is a clear correlation, and I think that the relationship is the result of the use that the Secord Amendment has, through its interpretations.

This is where the US's situation as the only country that addresses guns in this particular way becomes problematic. Without implementations of similar constitutional rights, the way the Second Amendment is used boils down to the current prevailing interpretation of the amendment. Your way of dealing with it can't be judged as aberrational or normative, because there is no class of similar things. But undeniably, your outcomes are shockingly aberrational: other civilzed people don't live the way you do.

The interpretation of the Second comes down to what specific cases are brought before the courts, and ultimately the Supreme Court. When asked to rule on the Second Amendment, the courts are constrained, usually by the context the case being heard provides.

The striking thing about this for a non United States citizen (I'm Canadian), is that that interpretation supports a hazy agreement to the premise, but doesn't examine the larger context – because the specific context of the test cases brought did not invite that. 

The NRA, and other advocacy groups have steered this interpretation, and have caused the current interpretation to be focused on an individual mandate to own a gun inherent in the 2nd. The verbiage about militias, well regulated, the temporal considerations, the historical conditions that framed its use are ignored. You only have to look at the Third Amendment to understand that these instruments are not always documents for the ages, but, frankly, hacks in some cases. The Second is one of those, but its use has changed.

Here's the basic, non-engineering problem: a sovereign state is an entity that holds a monopoly on violence. To be absolutely clear about this, a state is not an entity that gains, after its establishment, such a monopoly: the monopoly is the state. Starting with Hobbes, who the so called Founding Fathers knew the writings of intimately, the monopoly on violence is the state.

So in my reading the current interpretation, – expressed in any number of memes there for the reading January 6 in Washington – the Second Amendment is seen permitting any minority group of citizens to take up arms against a government that they, in their wisdom, declare to be despotic. This, in itself is a contradiction that the framers were exceedingly unlikely to have endorsed. And that was not the interpretation of the courts, on the few occasions that the Second found itself being interpreted, prior to the end of the Second World War.

But that interpretation of the Second is a very useful tool, in that it provides an unanswerable base to assert any kind of gun ownership at all, which is how most advocates for gun rights will, eventually, line up. All you have to do is accept the absurd proposition that a state would willingly not only permit, but encourage the preparation for, competing forces, fully armed, intent on using violence, to challenge the integrity of the entity that grants them that same right. 

Most people's, and perhaps that includes Destin's views may be much more nuanced, but there's no nuanced interpretation from the Supreme Court available: if you want to keep your guns, you're forced to take the current maximalist position. That means that many people of good faith find themselves in the same boat as some pretty dangerous people, and artificially separated by gun policy from people they agree with. No wonder the moderate struggles to be heard in your country.

In turn, this makes the gun rights tent a really big tent, one that holds the responsible gun owners, and the lunatic fringe, the Minutemen, the Militias, the preppers, and on down the line. Like the Republican Party's current crisis of direction, it prevents the US policy debate from flourishing, and seeking actual solutions, while holding the moderates hostage.

I'm writing this all here, because Destin's dedication and sincerity is as always on full view, and it's great. As a person whose rationalist credentials are impeccable, I see him as someone who is not on the other side of politics from me – even though, I, like most Canadians, and in fact most people everywhere, think guns are a blight, and a symptom of unaddressed problems.

This is the problem with the existing maximalist view of the Second, for Americans. We don't have the problem that you're trying to solve. What I'm trying to say is that the Second Amendment is another form of engineering, political engineering, done originally on sound engineering principles, but recently overadapted, and modified beyond its safe operating limits, and still running on the original fitness for use certification.

The Gun Detector is a response to, and an implicit acceptance of, the misapplication of basic principles, like a terrible computer patch meant to keep fundamentally flawed code running. It can be well engineered, but it can't repair the underlying broken system it's meant to extend.

While this is useful, there's not really anything new here. The fact that Destin said YouTube might suppress the video because it contains guns suggests that YouTube already deploys software to detect guns in video. This is basically the same as any other image recognition software, which is used not only in security but also in academic science for processing large data sets of images. Check out deep learning image analysis software like ORS Dragonfly for doing this. You could train it to efficiently learn how to identify anything in a stack of images. I would assume that security organizations have already developed more advanced image recognition software years ago, trained via deep learning to identify guns in images and video.
Also, while training deep learning software can be tedious, 30k images all trained by hand was probably a very inefficient way to do this. A more efficient deep learning training strategy is to kickstart the algorithms with some training data identifying guns manually, maybe start with 500 images, then have the software go through a huge amount of data automatically, you could even have it scour google images, or run through movies and sort the data by the confidence level. The high confidence data is likely all correct, but you should have a quick look through the results to see if the trained algorithm got them all correct, then focus your efforts mostly on auditing a portion of the middle confidence data, like maybe two hundred of the many thousands of images. Flip through the images and you only need to correct the mistakes, both false positive and false negative identification, while quickly passing through or approving the successful mid-confidence entries. Then run the deep learning automation program again to scour thousands of images automatically, and repeat auditing of a small portion of the middle range confidence data. Keep going through this iterative process, and the result will skew towards increasing the fraction of high confidence results while the count of data in other confidence levels shrinks. It's inefficient to hand-draw boxes over 30k images when with a more iterative and automated process you only need to do a few hundred at a time, a few times.

There is also something to be said about training a model to identify the stance and posture of someone brandishing a weapon. It is possible that a person could be far enough away from a camera that their gun does not provide enough data to the model, but if it were trained to use body posture/arm placements to help, especially in the situation that a gun has been positively identified and suspect is moving through the building. I am an avid gun enthusiast, and not ashamed AT ALL. With saying that, let me say this. It seems like a good starting idea, and obviously still in the works, but a couple observations. First, it's quite delayed, like it cant process the data fast enough. Second, obviously if the gun is out, it's probably too late and shootings are soon to happen. I don't believe that people should be X-rayed all the time, and I'm totally against that idea. But I would think that the goal would be to identify a gun before it's pulled out. Obviously guns can be quite small and easy to conceal, but I feel like abnormal shapes and lumps on the body could possinly be detected. Another thing could maybe be thermal imagery. I do work with thermals, and it is very obvious when a person is holding a gun when looking under thermals, but that's if they're holding it. What I'm wondering is, If the body gives off heat and a pistol is being carried in a waistband, would that cold steel portray a cold object under the shirt or in the pocket. Obviously up against the body it will warm up a little bit, but not to body temperature.

But either way, this is a good idea. I think it could best be used sort of like an amber alert. If a gun is detected out in the open and being held like that, the camera processes it and automatically sends a text alert with the location and maybe blurred face (in case it's innocent) but full view of clothes. That way if something is happening, people could know the location it's occurring at, leave the area if they're there, avoid the area if not there, and have an idea of what the suspect is wearing. Have a second program running simultaneously that alerts the police and doesn't blur the face. Even better if it could immediately go through a police database to match the identity and look for violent crimes in the past or if they're not even suppose to carry a firearm. But obviously it would need to ID a gun right away, have a n amazing confidence/accuracy, be on an alert system for both civilians and law enforcement, have some sort of facial recognition, and tied into police systems to run those rapid background checks for probability ratings. And that's a lot of work, programming, and resourcing to make happen.

As far as "school shootings"...this is a relatively new phenomena. Guns have been an ENORMOUS part of American culture for 250 years. School shootings started much more recently (Columbine was only 20 years ago in 1999). As any scientist knows, solving a problem starts with isolating the variables. Guns are not the variable that changed. Guns have been around and accessible since before our country's official existence (some 250 years). Something else changed. And, as any rational, logical, scientist would know, you'll never solve a problem without identifying the root cause. One of the symptoms of Polio is fever. You don't cure Polio by treating the fever with, say, Tylenol. Treating the symptom never cures the disease. Likewise, the availability and accessibility of guns was far easier for the majority of American history relative to school shootings. Attacking gun rights and accessibility is akin to fighting only the fever symptom of Polio without identifying the underlying cause.

You could hire VA's from the Philippines for $3-$5 per hour from Upwork and fiver to mine the internet for more images and have them continue to train the algos. It'd probably be better to start training at pretty significant distances though. Most security cameras are mounted at high locations with a wide field of view so if the goal is for this tech to be used in schools and other public places it'd likely be more efficient to start training the system based on security camera footage as it's not very likely that a pulled gun would ever get as close as they are to the webcam as they would to a security camera IRL. Also, as the algo gets better you can potentially use the algo itself to find/generate more images/videos for the training data.

Here's another idea: Though the footage wouldn't necessarily be easy to get your hands on, if you worked directly with military and/or law enforcement then maybe some of them would be willing to share some security footage from their training facilities as these would probably be the highest density of people walking around with guns while being recorded by security cameras you could find. Like I said, easier said than done but you probably couldn't find much better training data than that.

Also I don't really understand why your only focusing on pulled guns. Being able to track where all guns are at all times regardless if those guns are holstered or not seems like it would be overall beneficial. As a gun owner if I'm going to carry my firearm into a crowded place I expect people to notice that I have it and I don't think it violates my privacy for them to notice. If anything I want them to notice so A: they don't mess with me and B: so they know who to hide behind if something goes down. And if the security personnel of the place I'm going to gets notified the second I walk in the door that I have a gun then the same thing applies. If I'm a trouble maker and I'm going to use my gun to start problems they should know where I am or if something goes down and they need my help then they should know where to find me. Or if they explicitly don't want my help and they want to just make sure I stay out of it instead of trying to be a hero and possibly making things worse then, again, they should know where I am. So there's really no scenario where the security people behind the cameras should not at least be made aware that a gun, regardless of who it's attached to, or how it's attached to them, has entered their facility. Now there is definitely merit to having the system capable of distinguishing between pulled and holstered but it would probably be significantly better at figuring that out if it already verified that that person definitely has a gun.

And this tech doesn't need to be "x-ray" good to work but if someone is hiding a gun the people behind the cameras in basically every circumstance I can think of would need to know that they have it. The only way I can see that being a problem is if the people behind the cameras are racist and the person carrying the gun is of color but if the person carrying the gun is well within their legal rights then there's nothing the people behind the cameras can legally do (though I suspect in those kinds of situations the racist people would try to do something stupid anyway). But if we're going down that road then those problems would probably happen whether the security personnel know about the gun or not.

If your concern is that you want to carry a gun 24/7 even if that means carrying it into a place that doesn't allow guns then A: your playing with fire regardless of the security system they have and B: if it's really that important to you, you could probably get by with stashing a tiny one in your wife's purse or in a loose pocket or boot but if that's the case your probably not making anyone any safer and if a situation does happen where you need to pull it out the algo will definitely pick it up and you'll definitely go to jail so if your willing to take that risk then that's on you.

A lot of the times software developers don’t realize they haven’t used sufficient amount of darker skin tones, this is why hand motion detectors or facial recognition sometimes fails for darker people because the AI doesn’t have an equal ratio of information to learn from for darker tones.

Two ideas: User interface design & training the AI.

User interface: never contrast red and green because a very large percentage of the population is red-green color blind. Furthermore, because this particular distinction is extremely important, use multiple visual indicators to convey information. For example, in addition to the different color tags, use different geometric tags: maybe put a hexagon around a suspected gun and a rectangle around phones.

Training the AI: have users submit photos and videos. Provide instructions of the format requirements and how the user must tag the gun, phone, or other object. Most of the submissions should be mundane, especially in the beginning. Then challenge the users to submit videos that will create a false positive or a false negative. If a video creates an incorrect response, use it to improve the AI.

The technology to detect guns is one thing: whether those technologies will be adopted, by whom, and under what circumstances is another thing entirely.

As Everett Rogers observed in his classic Diffusion of Innovation, people adopt innovations for several reasons: because they know what the innovation is; because they know what the innovation is going to do for them; because they know how to make the innovation work for them; and because the innovation means something significant for them. So some people will oppose adoption of such technologies because their ideas about what the technology is for and what it means are different from the ideas other people hold.

The bottom line is that we must talk with rather than past one another, remembering that our mutually constructed social realities depend in large part upon assumptions we make that are often unchecked. We should be able to come to consensus on employment of these technologies, but doing so means recognizing that we each approach the discussion from the perspective of differing social realities: we can't assume we know what the other thinks about the subject.

We can do this if we are respectful of one another and don't automatically assume that others have hostile opinions about our positions. But that's a lot harder a thing to do than devise a technology to detect an object.

That wear-down will prevent the slide STOP lever from functioning properly and may allow the slide to move forward when you don’t intend it to. This could result in an unsafe situation.

Instead of releasing the slide stop lever with your thumb, grab your slide with your other hand and punch forward with your grip hand. This will release the pressure on the slide stop allowing the slide stop to return to a neutral position with less friction. Tactical, this is better as well as it allows you to put sights on target faster. The best way to grip your slide is an over the top grip to give you a full-hand grip of your slide. I’m sure you can see many examples of that if you search “tap and rack.”

2:02 "so if it's a 1, it knows without a doubt it's a gun". I'm gonna seriously nitpick here, because while it may seem like semantics, false positive/negative rate is VERY important with safety matters.
"It knows" - I know, you know, but maybe some people in the audience don't know - the computer doesn't "know". It's churning a pile of math and getting an answer.
"without a doubt" - The detector can only ascribe a value 0 to 1. This is commonly referred to as a probability (since both measure 0 to 1) but this is not the same as, 99% means a 1-in-100 chance it's not a gun. It gets even more complicated with multiclass and non-max-suppression.
"it's a gun" - Again, the detector only knows the little world of images it has seen and how they have been labeled. Humans see thousands of "frames" a day and thousands of classes of objects. I'm glad your engineer friend tried to include many adversarial examples. But it's important to stress to anyone looking at results of AI systems that just because the algo says "100% it's a gun" does not mean it is. In fact towards the end you could see where it flags the satellite as 100% gun.
/end engineer nitpick

IMHO: Seems like a good idea at first glance, but I have doubts about its practicality (I do note a couple possible uses at the end of this post though).
First question that popped in my mind: I don't think phones are the most items that look the most like a gun. So many elctrical tools would, I presume, look more like a gun. This system on a hardware store (where it could otherwise, as in any store, be very useful) would go completely crazy, and so would any security guard that might be looking at the "detections"...
Speaking of the "security guard", there is also the concern of over-automation: would the system only flash a warning so a human would check it or ... would it trigger something more automatic (instant sirens, instant call to the police, ...)?...
There are also other things that would look like a gun: hair-driers for instance. I'm not even trying to come up with stuff, they're just effortlessly popping on my head...
Also, on the guns themselves, I noticed only handguns were appearing. But there has been gun violence with rifles, shotguns, ...

There is also one last problem I can think of, which actually also makes me think of a positive potential. First the negative: I agree that, where guns are allowed to be carried, looking for guns that are being carried, but not drawn out, should not happen. However, if the gun is already drawn out, how much time do you have to prevent the person with the gun from fire it? Seems a bit pointless.


However, a benefit occurred to me: It's a dark thought, and I'd presume a sort of unlikely occurrence, but I think it could be useful for forensic police work in a particular type of situation. For instance, if a dead body were to be found, with bullet wound(s), but it had been moved from the place it had been shot at. Looking for evidence of the shooting on hours of (possibly) many surveillance cameras in the area might be a near impossible task (again, I'd presume). But if one of these cameras would have spotted a gun drawn out (using this system), and recorded the video and the time, then it would be much quicker to look only at those small periods of time and therefore view the shooting and possibly identify the shooter.
And now I think of it, it could even be useful to save lives, in the case of a kidnap at gun point. This system might provide clues as to the destination and whereabouts of the kidnapper(s) and their victim(s).

If we were to tie directly to data sources from the gun detection system it can instantly trigger those sigange systems to alert the facility or facilities about the active shooter and the location data, just like it would for fire alarms. I am by no means an expert but I have just finished writing a thesis on object detection using deep leaning algorithms and I can see some possible issues in your training data set that could possibly be causing some performance issues.


Namely a lot of the training data seems to be high quality images taken close up to the gun which I don't think properly reflects the kind of images you would get from a security camera. Security cameras are generally low quality, positioned at a high angle and it is unlikely they would ever get such a close up view of the gun. Perhaps some artificial training data augmentation such as randomized down scaling, brightness and contrast adjustment and image rotation could help make the detector more robust.


The image down scaling may improve the ability for the network to detect the gun when it is relatively far away, but something I found in my project was that the relative size of the object in frame also had an effect on performance. The objects i was detecting were anywhere from 20-100 pixels in size so I implemented a system where the input image is sliced into crops run through the detector and then stitched back together and it massively improved the performance. however it does lead to slower processing times as the network has to run multiple times per image so it may not work as well for your real-time application.


Anyway, you may have already thought of these things but I thought I'd put them out there just in case you hadn't. Really cool project though, interested to see where it goes in the future.

From prior security experience I can give some advice and perspective on a the detector bit. I would be willing to bet significant amount of money one of the primary reasons the company immediately stopped having interest in your product if it is unable to detect a weapon prior to being drawn... By that time for the people nearby it is too late. For people on scene they will have a chance, if they recognize the threat in time, to react and pull their own firearm or attempt to disarm the suspect/shooter. While the program may be able to detect the INSTANT a gun is pulled, if you assume people will need time to be warned or get assistance on location it will likely be too late for those in immediate danger. This is why prevention systems that are so invasive are currently in major use. Depending on location even a courthouse with nearby police station / sheriff's office could take a few minutes to get the closest person on duty to the scene.

I could genuinely see the use as a system to be used in tandem with most current security setups. Many higher end security systems have similar such things already being made for private markets. Facial recognition software among others is a great example of this same tech being used in a different setting. Advice for marketing and practice to the system software would be to ask locations that have high traffic (Courthouse entrances, major business entrances, industrial production sites) if they would be interested in setting up the system as a direct warning system for when things go wrong. As an example in a courthouse setting having Lantern setup overlooking a main doorway could be helpful in worst case scenarios. The moment a firearm is pulled either the security is responding to an incoming threat, or a threat has just started. At that moment the nearest law enforcement agency (or agency setup to receive the warning) would be issued a notice to call attention to the situation instantly. This means security can deal with the threat without needing to split their focus between communicating the event and the danger to the nearby personnel.

Making sure it works with existing surveillance cameras was a great decision, and the target audience will have a good use for the product. Just realize that you should be targeting more civilian and lower end government buildings (city/county/possibly state) since there are other competing technology at use in higher level locations.

In systems like this, it's important to realize and take advantage of "the power of crappy sensors", where a bunch of crappy sensors can be combined to yield a system that is far more than the sum of its crappy parts.

Let's say the video-based "gun in-hand" sensor is useful only 5% of the time, because the gun may be one it wasn't trained on, or is in a bag or pocket, or the shooter's back is to the camera, or the shooter is too far away, or the lighting is too dim, or any of a number of other failure criteria. Does that mean we shouldn't use this sensor?

Before answering that question, let's look at what else we can add to the mix.

1. Sound-based "shots fired" sensor, generally audio-based (microphones), but flash detectors and smoke detectors may also be used.
2. "Body flow" sensors. hallway traffic sensors that learn normal human flows to detect abnormal flows (such as all traffic going in one direction at an unusual time for that flow).
3. Emotional state trackers, basically facial recognition systems that identify general emotions rather than specific identity.

The list goes on. Notice how many of the above can make use of the same video stream used by the system in this video. That is to say, a single video camera can feed multiple sensors/detectors. And notice how inexpensive the non-video sensors are.

The next step is to combine all the separate sensors to yield much better information, a process called "sensor fusion". For example, if all the sensors in one area simultaneously report low-confidence detections, it would be sensible to assign a much higher overall detection confidence to that area.

I won't get into the analysis, but doing multiple rounds of video analysis (preferably in parallel) combined with a few other inexpensive sensors (such as smoke, flash, sound detectors), can provide vastly more reliable detection information.

I've seen the research around the radio-wave and microwave type detectors, and they're not as invasive as they might seem. Basically, they detect firearms by listening for a disruption in the radio response similar to how metal detectors work. The idea is that firearms are made of metal, so if you flag someone who has a large chunk of metal on their person that's about waist height off the ground, it's more suspicious than if you have that same response around mid-back height. There will be false positives, but the idea is that it's better to have a soft maybe than a hard false negative.
The main idea is that anyone who makes one of those flags is tracked via camera systems at which point it looks for other flags like if their face is obscured, if they have a bag on them. The idea isn't to x-ray everyone and see what they look like naked, the idea is to look for a particular response to a broadcast signal. Such devices aren't any more an invasion of privacy than the camera system you're working with. The groups working on them have been very careful to avoid techniques that could be considered an invasion of privacy.
Segnex, one of the companies I've researched appears to have a system that seems to just look for microwave responses, making it certain that someone has a weapon with no more detail than a general outline of a person due to the frequency of microwaves being capable of being tuned to a resolution no clearer than recognizing broad outlines.

Also: would attachments thwart detection? I suppose both can be solved with (a lot) more training of a lot more different guns.

This also raises a third larger question: Will detection ever be good enough? Or if not, is the improvement worth the false positives and false negatives? IMO the last question comes down to a communication thing, and how people see e tech. They should see it like the engineers do: "It gives you better information than having no system, but you still have to remember the system is imperfect and can be wrong sometimes, so everything needs human judgment and a cool head to interpret it." And in this case, machine learning and surveillance is not a replacement for human judgment. Just early warning that something may be going on. And some positional information as you point out in the video. That is security cams' strong suit is placing a person at a specific place/time.

Some people think machines are never wrong. We need people to start to understand that the harder problems we throw at machines, the more likely there will be some edge cases where it is impossible or unlikely for the machine to get it right. But the machine is still useful as an early warning system.

The detector knows where the gun is at all times. It knows this because it knows where the gun isn't. By subtracting where it is is from where it isn't, or where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to correct the detector into finding the gun from a position it is, based on a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.

I do not know much about the subject yet, but I am having trouble understanding how you can say with absolute certainty (confidence level of 1.00) that something is a gun. This would mean that the AI model literally is incapable of making a mistake, which is unrealistic and also not true. As you pointed out the model reported a false positive on the thing hanging from the ceiling. False positives are not uncommon in AI, but that fact that they do happen means that you can not realistically report a 100% confidence level on an object if the model is fallible (which it is and which it will most likely remain).


What also interests me is how a false positive can still have a confidence level of 1.00. To me it seems that there is something seriously wrong with the model if this happens. At my internship I am currently getting up to speed on detecting cars and I also have to deal with false positives, but in my experience false positives really shouldn't occur in the higher confidence levels. If my model is 10% certain that something is a car and it gets it wrong, that is perfectly acceptable since it wasn't too sure about it in the first place. However if my model gets a false positive on a 100% confidence level I would be seriously worried about my model.

This is one of those technologies that under the right circumstances could work well, but under many circumstances, wouldn't.  It can contribute to accelerating a first response in an active shooter situation if the gun is in plain view of the camera, but if a shooter was aware of the tech at a particular school or workplace, it would be trivial to defeat it by wrapping the gun in a bag, or painting it with "dazzle" patterns, etc.   So here is my tech recommendation:  Microphones, and software that can detect any of the following:  A gunshot......screaming.......or people shouting the word GUN or SHOOTER, or any sound that is loud enough to qualify as an attempt at active interference.  The presence of any of those sounds triggers a 911 call.  Microphones are cheap, easy to install all over a building, you can't easily defeat it, and you give the targets in a shooting scenario control to trigger the system, just by yelling or screaming as panic ensues.  Microphones are less invasive than cameras, so it is more acceptable to put them in bathrooms, locker rooms, or other private places.  This would be much more reliable, and much simpler to deploy in 1000s of buildings.  The tech could then be expanded to detect shouted words like:  FIRE, or HELP, or BOMB, or OUT OF TOILET PAPER, and get much needed help on the way quickly.

Reiterating a point here that is getting drowned out. As other have indicated, once the gun is drawn, it is probably too late to prevent a shooting -- but that's not what this system is for. This is not a solution to gun violence. It is, however, a valid approach to reduce the effects that violence may have. Through that lens, this has tremendous potential value.

Imagine a facility, like a school, where all the doors instantly lock when a detection occurs. Window covers are installed that automatically deploy. People are notified. Announcements go out. Access to critical systems and information is orchestrated to reduce response times. Police are instantly notified, and access to the camera system is provided to first responders. Announcements go out, and a response plan is put into place. That response plan can be forced upon potential victims whether they are aware of the need or not.

A system such as this can turn that response into a matter of seconds, whereas current response plans might take minutes. This could save lives. You can't put a price tag on that.

I respect the effort that's being made here, and the work that went into this project, but a I have several concerns that have been raised by a few other commenters already, but I figure if I voice them again it can't hurt.

1. While the technology and project is still developing, I understand the issue of time/resources vs efficacy/accuracy however it still appears that there are many false positives and negatives still happening at this time. I'm sure with more data in the system those will decrease, however almost all of the images provided to the algorithm have been of reasonably clear shots and angles, and not from traditional low quality surveillance footage. Up close recognition is good, but wouldn't help in a traditional active shooter situation.
2. The only images I saw being used in the algorithm, and the only firearms used in the demonstration here are of handguns. In many of the largest and most damaging cases of gun violence, hand guns were not used. Semi-automatic rifles have been the largest culprit of mass gun death in recent years, and this algorithm fails to address those firearms yet. And while you could add those to the database, it will take many more hours of recognition and frame logging to accurately produce a viable recognition on those as well.
3. This program does not factor in a concealed firearm aspect. If the shooter wished to keep the situation more chaotic, or if they were aware of this technology they would seek to conceal the firearm underneath a towel, within another object, or only use the firearm out of sight from camera positions. You could then make the argument that more cameras could be used, with additional angles, but then you stray closer to the 4th amendment concern.
4. This addresses a symptom, and attempts to alleviate the tragedy of a larger issue. And while the effort in trying to mitigate harm is admirable and a worthy cause, it doesn't deal with the issue from a preventative stance. It's only reactionary and is only useful after a firearm has been drawn, and likely already been fired.

Overall the technology is cool, and the work is impressive. However I find it's implementation and efficacy to be weak. There are better solutions to gun violence than a reactionary option for first responders to utilize.

My gut response is mixed on this. Being able to provide real time information to first responders is excellent, but there has been so, so much abuse of law enforcement by people that are opposed to firearm ownership that I think we need to ask how we're going to address the personal security aspect of this issue.

In particular I'm thinking about the man that was shot to death by the police in a Walmart because another customer saw him with a toy rifle and called 911.

A system like this might have saved his life by allowing the officers time to assess enroute instead if making a split second decision, but it could just as easily be used to designate targets for this sort of action. It all depends on the intent of the people using it, and we can no longer expect that all of those people are honorably pursuing public safety.

In a real sense, this is the same situation as the firearm itself. The technology is neutral, but the people wielding it are not. It's arguably someone's right to operate this software as a measure of self-defense, but what assurances do we have that it won't be used to obtain an ad-hoc registry of firearms owners, for example? For however much longer Walmart has an inventory of firearms, if I buy one from them there is some point in the transaction at which I'm likely to flag some algorithm like this one. At a gun shop with a firing range that's even more likely, as there is a place where I could safely discharge the firearm.

The desire to establish a national firearms registry exists in some politicians. The will to do it through conventional means currently doesn't, though, and I absolutely wouldn't put it past a few of those to attempt to sneak it in the backdoor using software like this. How do we avoid a PRISM style program built around this technology?

If you coded the computer to look at several images at once to identify the gun, that would make the system more accurate. When you showed the camera the magazine port of the gun, it recognized it as a cell phone, but if you programed it to recognize different patterns, (like a barrel pointing out from a handle someone is holding) and take a photo of that frame, it could recognize that magazine port as the same one it saw in the frame it took the picture of, and it could identify the gun more accurately. One issue with the system you are using is that if someone covered up the gun with something to disguise it, like a paper bag or a shirt, the system might not identify it. You could fix this by training the system to identify a persons stance and an arm/both arms extended. You could include the terahertz technology with that, so that it focuses on whatever the person is holding. This way, it wouldn’t invade the persons privacy if it is a false alarm, but will be effective in identifying an assailant. Another thing you could do is include facial expressions, both of the person holding the possible gun, and the people around them if any. You could also code the system to identify if people are running away from the person (possibly) holding a gun. To ensure that the system identifies the firearm as fast as possible, you could configure the order of operations like this:
Visible firearm recognition>assailants stance>terahertz>facial expression>fleeing from assailant.
One other issue is a variety of toy guns, such as nerf guns, paintball, and airsoft. Since paintball and airsoft guns are typically reminiscent of real firearms, and many real firearms are painted in bright colors, just like nerf guns, it would be very, very hard to reliably identify an airsoft/nerf/paintball gun as a toy, not a gun, and a gun as a firearm, not a toy. For one, the average person does not need a thirty round magazine. It's overkill for hunting. I hunt hog, deer, elk, coyote, and more. Not a one of those animals have been too much for a bolt action rifle I choose to hunt with most of the time or a five shot tube-fed semi-auto. Not every shot will be great and a followup shot (or two) should be possible. A hunter who needs more than two shots to kill an animal is a bad hunter and gives hunters a bad image. They don't care about shot placement and rather fill their target animal with multiple rounds to compensate for poor accuracy.


The only other reason to have it is competitive sport shooting. Competitive sport shooters should be licensed and documented. They should have psychological evaluations prior to licensing and being allowed to purchase assault rifle platforms and high-capacity magazines that can only be used within the competitive sport shooting scene. No taking them on a hunt, no lazy-day firing in the country. They can only be in the weapon on a firing range.


The second issue is a lack of accountability . Very few of the parents/guardians/friends/etc were criminally convicted after an underage shooter used their firearm to kill people. A third issue is that we have to stop placing blame on the media/movies/tv/videogames for gun violence. Millions of ingest violent content in some way. Dozens actually go out and shoot people. Tighter background checks, psychological evaluations, proper gun safety classes at the middle-school level and higher, a restriction on unnecessary armaments (see point one) and more.

I work in tech support and am a pilot. I think part of the usefulness of a tool like this is to act as a filter of the information going into the responder's mind. In tech support it's the idea of when an item reaches a critical threshold an alarm is sounded with an alert in a report or dashboard. In an airplane the same thing happens, something reaches a critical threshold triggers something.

How do you apply this technology then? First, speed up the process. The sooner you can get alerted that there's a critical threshold the sooner you can react to the information.

Second, do things to widen the scope of the inputs. Would two cameras work better to improve the confidence levels of the detectors?

Finally though, look at the application from a command and control standpoint. Go to a place with a lot of people, sit in the control room, and follow a person as they're walking along. It's difficult to do when there's no chaos, imagine the people are running. Teach the system to soak up the information in the chaos, chew through the data, and the export the information in a human readable format.

You're well versed in systems design and consideration. You're getting involved in the inputs to the system, now you just need to refine the processing of that input, and the output of the results in as human readable as possible.

Having worked with object detection myself and computer vision, I can tell from experience that it is very easy to get a proof of concept "working" like this one, but extremely difficult to make it a viable working product. There are so many problems I can already tell just from this video:

1. You trained your algo on movies with cinematic angles on guns, but you want to detect guns on security camera footage, where the angle is wide, far and from above. I'm 100% sure it won't detect anything on low res security camera footage since you didn't train it in the conditions you want it to work.
2. The program is a frame by frame detector, not an actual video footage detector. You got no "frame over frame tracking" that could help with those false positives.
3. The amount of false positives is way to high.
4. Even with the impressive amount of data you got, it can't even detect the gun at several angles, point blank at the camera in near perfect conditions.
5. What about other types of guns ( other than handguns ) ?

It's a neat trick, but that's it.

While this idea is great, it has three very severe flaws:
1. It's nearly impossible to train. Your entire dataset is just people holding pistols up close, just like on the webcam. Try doing it across the room at an angle, or holding a rifle, or holding a completely black gun, or covering it with your hand.

This part is super important to understand.
An artificial neural net has the same algorithm (ie feed the input through each layer of neurons once) regardless of what it's supposed to be doing. This is a time complexity of O(1), and is one of the main advantages an ANN has. Each neuron contains the mathematical relationships between certain inputs and the output(0, 1) it produces. The calculation is the same each time, only variables being changed according to training and input.

The only ways you can improve an ANN are to either increase the size of the net, give it more information(in this case higher res cameras), improve the dataset's size and quality, change the training algorithm, or allow additional training time (if you're using a genetic algorithm for training).

Hmm, I am not entirely sure how to feel about this project. It's a logical step to take, and a path that has been explored quite a bit in the past. I remember a project from many years ago where people were trying to detect suspicious behavior in crowds and live "fingerprinting" through gate-recognition. I mean yes, the fastest way probably to report an active shooter situation would indeed be to somehow recognize the gun, and submit an image (either short video or still) directly to authorities, and personally I have nothing against it, but from a larger privacy perspective with today's state of machine learning, there will be lots of false positives (see examples in this video where a light on the ceiling was recognized as a gun, and more concerning the 100% accuracy reported which is impossible so I suspect some rounding going on here), and so there will be images transmitted when they really shouldn't be. Think of it as an Alexa/Google Home situation, where there are constantly snippets of recorded audio transmitted because the device thinks it recognized a prompt. That being said, yeah you can definitely keep building this out to an even greater tool for fighting gun violence (improve recognition with synthetic training data, add pose-recognition, etc.), where I probably see more value in this at a larger scale, predicting the future movement of a shooter (or group of shooters) through an inside or outside space. Of course, even using machine learning for tactical benefit is something that is being explored quite heavily as well. What really concerns me about these projects is the nature of humans and how we always manage to go step by step into futures we do not see the full consequence of yet.

The process of how the system alerts should be able to be set up by the end user. But I think it would work very well like this.

1, The system detects a subject with a firearm.
2, The system sends an alert. This alert goes to the staff at the school, and to central disbatch via SMS.
3, It is determined by humans if there is an active firearm or not. If everyone at the school got an alert, they can see if its a false positive or not. This allows the staff to go into lockdown and for staff to trip off alarms if they are present.
4, If its a false alarm, the system can be notified that its a false alarm, and it can be rearmed. If there is no rearm signal, the system assumes there is an active shooter and continues.
5, The system then continuously send SMS alerts to disbatch to show where the subject is in the building.
6, The system will continue to send images of firearms to disbatch, (even of the officers). I think its important to send images regardless, so someone cannot impersonate a police officer.
